p: Africa is recognized as particularly challenging in terms of human development progress among the world’s developing regions [ 1]. Of the variety of political, economic, and environmental reasons, the continent’s disproportionate extent of drylands [ 2] and vector-borne diseases are major contributing factors [ 3]. Drylands, which include hyper-arid to dry sub-humid climate zones (Fig. 1) are naturally characterized by dust storms, temperature extremes, variable rainfall and drought, low agricultural productivity, and zoonotic and vector-borne disease emergence [ 2]. These natural hazards, already exaggerated in drylands, are exacerbated anthropogenically through deforestation and land degradation [ 4], dams and irrigation projects [ 5], pesticide and anti-microbial use, vector and pathogen resistance [ 6], and political conflict [ 7]. Adding to this, global climate change is predicted to contribute to increasing climate extremes and drought severity in African drylands [ 8]. The increased climate variability will further challenge conventional vector borne disease control efforts and require adaptive approaches that include, among other tools, novel meteorological forecasting platforms [ 9].
